quote: Captain's log, Stardate 42680.3.   We are the first manned vessel   to enter the Selcundi Drema   quadrant. Previous unmanned   probes have recorded unusual   levels of geological activity   in all five planetary systems.   I am hoping the Enterprise will   find the answer to this engima.
Commander, I have been reviewing   the unmanned probe scans. In the   past one hundred and fifty years,   the fifth planet of Selcundi Drema   has shattered, forming an asteroid   belt.
I'd call that geological   instability.
Is there any indication that this   is the work of an unknown   intelligence?
I think this is geology, not   malevolence. These planets live   fast and die hard. The question   is why.
You're sure you won't reconsider?
No, I'll watch you and be   impressed.
An optimistic vote of confidence   from the non-rider.
I've never thought of you as   particularly an animal person.
Small animals, no, but horses --
Computer, program Holodeck for   a woodland setting with a bridle   path and an appropriate mount.
Type of mount? Andorian Zabathu,   Klingon Sark --
A horse, an Earth horse.
Breed?
Arabian.       The Arabs believed that Allah   gathered the south wind and made   the horse.
On the Holodeck we've made that   legend come true.
I like that. Oh yes, computer,   English tack, and I will control   the animal myself.
Acknowledged.
Hello, my beauty.
So you like horses for the   romance?
It goes deeper than that. A fine   war mare would sleep in a   bedouin's tent, carry him into   battle, feed his children with   her milk. There is a bond which   forms from mutual need.
Now I understand. You don't want   the comfort of a pet. You want   a companion.
I had a Betazoid kitten once. My   mother and the cat reacted...   badly to one another.
Captain, my mother and I share   a bond. She is going through a   difficult time, and I may need   to be with her.
If you want leave, you need only   ask.
Thank you, sir, I appreciate that.
You're sure you won't try? It's   a good way to relax. We can get   you something quiet and gentle.
No, no. I prefer a mode of   transportation that doesn't have   a mind of its own.
Strange. I should have thought   that Betazoids would be   outstanding animal trainers.
We become too involved in the   thoughts and shifting passions   of the beast. We lose our way   and become swept up in   emotionalism.
I should think the shifting   passions of...       ... this beast would be   far more terrifying.
Captain.
Yes, Number One?
We've entered the first system.   I think you might want to come   to the bridge.
Something interesting?
Spectacular and a little   terrifying.
On my way.    (he pats the horse's     neck)   Later, old girl.
This is our first long-range   reading, extremely high   magnification.
Quite impressive.
And deadly. The last unmanned   probe showed a thriving   ecosystem. Now there's nothing.
This is Commander Riker's meeting.

I need your advice and   recommendations. I was given the   responsibility of overseeing   Wesley's education. To further   that goal I want to put him in   command of the planetary mineral   surveys.
This is a big job with a lot of   responsibility.
The game's not big enough if it   doesn't scare you a little.
To do the job, Wesley's going to   need a team. It takes command   presence to lead. Is he ready   for that?
Leadership grows from   self-confidence which is also   part of a Starfleet officer's   education.
All of this is true, but there   is an old horse trainer's adage   about putting too much weight on   a young back -- we don't want him   to break under the pressure.

We seem to be shifting the focus   here. Are we talking about a   young officer on the fast track   to the Academy or are we talking   about guiding a young man through   adolescence and into adulthood?
Both.
You can't guide someone into   adulthood. The experiences are   unique to each person. Whether   Wes succeeds or fails, he will   learn from the experience.
I agree. I'm just questioning   the speed at which we're moving.
You think we're pushing him too   hard?
It's a valid concern.
Tempering is done in extremes.
He's a boy, not a sword.
Who will someday be a man and   need a fine edge that will hold,   that won't dull at the first   touch of resistance.
Sooner or later he's got to feel   the burden of command.
Mister Crusher to the Observation   Lounge.
Wesley, I'm placing you in   command of the planetary mineral   surveys.
Sir! Um... thank you, sir.
You may not thank me once you see   how much work it entails.   Assemble your team, and take a   look at the records on the Drema   quadrant. We've got a mystery   to solve here.
Yes, sir. A team, sir?
Ensign, this is a serious   responsibility.
I know, sir.

These officers are here to assist   you. Not judge, but help. I   suggest you use them; they are   a valuable resource. And by the   way, I have more respect for an   officer who knows when to admit   ignorance and ask a question than   one who, out of pride, will   blunder blindly forward.
I understand.
You're dismissed, Mister Crusher.
I'll try not to disappoint you
Is this part of your regular   duties?
No, a personal project. I have   just reset the sensors to scan   for frequencies outside their   usual range.
Such as?
The dips and peaks of the galaxy's   magnetic field, organic molecules   in nebular clouds, energetic   cosmic rays.
Interesting. Would these scans   also detect artificial   transmissions as well as naturally   occurring signals?
Of course.
Good.
Those signals are very faint and   difficult to distinguish from   background noise, which is why   I am boosting the power.
I will be removing this equipment   to my quarters.
Good!
Hi, may I walk with you? I need   a little advice.
Yes.
And it's free.
Walking or advice?
Both.
It's about my team. I'm   considering so many factors I'm   confusing myself.
What have you done so far?
Broken down the task and picked   the best people in those   disciplines.
Who have you got so far?
Prixus for mineralogy and   metallurgy, Alans and Hildebrant,   volcanology and geo-mechanics,   and I want Davies for geo-chemistry,   but --
But they're all older than   you?
Yeah, it makes me feel awkward.   And what about compatibility --
Completely irrelevant. They're   professionals. And if there are   personality conflicts, you resolve   them. You're in charge.
So you not only have to understand   the job, you have to be a ship's   counselor.
Sometimes.
Well, thanks.

Captain's log, Stardate 42680.7.   We are entering the second   Selcundi star system. I believe   the volatility of these planets   originated in the primordial gas   cloud which formed them five   billion years ago.
Computer, identify.
Sensors indicate low-level R.F.   waves.
Is there a pattern?
Affirmative.
Naturally occurring?
Negative.
Key universal translator.
Unable to comply. Weak signal.
Lock on com link and boost.
Lock on complete.
Read.
Working.
Ensign Davies?
You got him.
Wesley Crusher.
I've been put in charge of the   planetary survey, and I'd like   to have you on the team.
Sounds great. Who else is on it?
Prixus and Hildebrant and Alans.
It's a shame you didn't talk to   me first. Personal opinion, but   I like to break up married teams.
Oh, I hadn't thought about that.
Don't worry, they'll probably work   out fine.
And if you need any help, just   give me a signal and I'll take   over for you. We don't want you   getting too beat up on your first   command.
Uh... thanks, but I think I'll   be okay.
Analysis complete.
Enhance.
Is anybody out there?
Yes.
Wes.
Hi, Doctor Pulaski.
Is there trouble behind that door?
My team's in there. I've got to   assign planets, set a schedule.
Sounds like you've got everything   under control.
But I haven't had to deal with   them. Not all together. Not   professionally.
Wes, the minute you walk through   that door they're your team. You   don't have to prove a thing.   You've got the authority.
Only because Commander Riker says   I do.
It's up to you to hang on to it.    (a head jerk toward     the door)   You better get in there.
And for whatever it's worth, I   think you're going to do just   fine.       Or not.
It has been six weeks since our   entrance into the Selcundi Drema   quadrant. Each system has   revealed the same disturbing   geological upheavals on every   planet.
Program complete. Enter when   ready.
Feels good, doesn't it? You're   a lovely darling.
I agree. Nice job.
Here are the results of my scan   of the third Selcundi system.   Just the same old song.
Didn't you tell me that U.V.   absorption readings like these   are indicative of traker deposits?
And where there's traker there's   generally dilithium? Yeah, I did.
Then don't you think we ought to   run an Ico-spectrogram?
Those tanker readings are really   faint. It's probably a fool's   echo.
I think I'd still run the   Ico-gram.
Wesley, it's a major undertaking   to set up that scanner.
We're looking at five hours -- minimum.
I know, I just don't want to do   the job halfway.
Wes, there's being thorough and   then there's wasting time. It's   also the mark of a good officer   to recognize the difference.
Well, maybe you're right.
Access all volcanic and tectonic   plate activity of Drema Four.
Accessing.
Computer, locate Captain Picard.
Captain Picard is on Holodeck   Three.
I am sorry to disturb you,   Captain.
Quite all right. It must be   important, or you wouldn't be   here.
Yes, Captain, it is important.   Very. Eight weeks ago I received   a transmission -- a simple four   word message: "Is anybody out   there?" I answered it.
I could not help myself.
There is a loneliness inherent   in that whisper in the darkness.
Yes, I am glad that you   understand.
But it didn't stop there.
No. I have been drawn into her   life.
To what degree is this   involvement?
We have been communicating   regularly.
Dear heaven, you've got a pen pal.   Does this society have any idea   that there is interstellar life?
No.
Merde. Just where does she think   you're calling from?

I have kept that somewhat vague.   But Sarjenka has been quite   specific, telling me detailed   stories of her family and friends.   It was fascinating, but among   these confidences were interspersed   alarming references.
Go on.
Captain, Drema Four is enduring   the same geological stresses we   have found in the other systems.
Then your pen pal is in trouble.
Yes, sir.
What are you proposing?
If we can determine the cause of   the geological instability, we   might be able to reverse the   process.
And violate the Prime Directive.
I was hoping that you might have   an option.
We don't even know if this   catastrophe is preventable.       Call a conference in my   quarters. All senior   staff.
Yes, sir.
And Data, all communication with   this life-form must stop.
Yes, sir. I understand.
Will you excuse me?
You have the look of someone who   didn't come up here to relax.
No, sir, I need your advice.
Yesterday Ensign Davies turned   in his survey results. I thought   he should run an Ico-spectrogram.   He didn't agree.
Did you think you were right?
Well, yeah, I guess. Or I could   have just been picking nits.
Or perhaps intimidated? It's   tough to tell people what to do.
I suppose I could have made it   an order, but that's the hard   part. How do I give orders to   somebody older and more   experienced then me?
Your and Davies's relative ages   aren't the issue here. Are they?
I guess not.
Do you think it might have   something to do with ego?
Maybe the opposite of ego. Every   time I give an order, there's this   part of me that's asking what   makes my judgment so superior to   this other person's.

Wes, authority and responsibility   go hand in hand. I know you're   responsible, now you have to learn   to handle authority. You've been   put in command so you can make   a few right decisions. That will   establish a pattern of success   and build your self-confidence.   That's why I said this was about   ego. If you don't trust your own   judgment, you don't belong in the   command chair.
But what if I'm wrong?
Then you're wrong. It's arrogant   to think you'll never make a   mistake.
But what if it's something really   important -- not just a mineral   survey, and what if someone ends   up dead because of my mistake?
In your situation you only have   to do one thing: Ask yourself,   what would Picard do?
He'd listen to all the opinions,   then make the decision. But he's   Picard.
Doesn't matter. Would anyone   argue with the captain once his   decision was made?
No way.
Why not?
I'm not sure.
Commander Riker, report to the   captain's quarters.
When you've worked it out, you'll   understand command.
On my way.
I hope I've helped. Let me know   what you decide.
I've already decided. I'm going   to have Davies run that Ico-gram.       And thank you, sir.
You're welcome.
Hey, Wes, hi.
Ensign Davies, I want that   Ico-spectrogram run on the Selcundi   Drema system.
You got it.
You see the dilemma?
There are no options. The Prime   Directive is not a matter of   degree. It is an absolute.
I've always had a problem with   that kind of abstract   intellectualizing. It seems very   callous and even a little   cowardly.

Doctor, I'm sure the lieutenant   did not intend it in that way.   In this situation we must use   caution. Our actions could have   a profound effect upon the future.   If we could see all possible   outcomes --
We would be gods, but we're not.   If there is some cosmic plan,   isn't it the height of hubris to   presume that we can, or should,   interfere?
So what are you saying? That the   Dremans are fated to die?
It's something that needs to be   considered.
Well, consider it considered, and   rejected.
If there is a cosmic plan, are   we not part of it? Our presence   at this place at this moment in   time might be part of that fate.
So it might be part of the plan   that we interfere.
I think that eliminates the idea   of "fate."
Commander, remember "Human   reason needs only to will more   strongly than fate, and she is   fate."

Doctor, you quote Thomas Mann,   and Commander Riker could no doubt   cite Euripides to support his   position, but all of this is just   philosophy. Sarjenka is not a   subject for philosophical debate,   she is a person.
He's got a point. The Prime   Directive was designed to protect,   not destroy.
So Doctor, you draw the line at   the death of millions.
Yes.
Same situation if it's an epidemic   rather than a geological   catastrophe?
Absolutely.
How about a war? A   generations-long conflict that   is killing millions. Do we   interfere?
Now we're less secure in our moral   certitude. And what if it's not   death. What if it's an oppressive   government which is enslaving   millions?
The Prime Directive serves many   purposes. Not the least of which   is to protect us. It keeps   us from allowing our emotions to   overrule our judgement.
My emotions are involved. Data's   friend is going to die. That   means something.
To Data.
Does that invalidate the   emotion?
If the Dremans asked for our help?
Yes, Sarjenka's transmission could   be viewed as a call for help.
That's sophistry and you know it.
Hell, I'll buy that excuse. We're   all jigging madly on the head of   a pin anyway.
She cannot ask for help from   people she does not know.
She knows me.
What a perfectly vicious little   circle.
I want you to sever the remaining   com link with Drema Four.

Captain, to maintain contact   without subspace radio capability   required the computer to remotely   scan all subspace resonance in her   area. If I break that link the   probability of relocating her   signal falls to one in twenty-three   million...
We are going to allow her to die,   are we not?
Data, Data! Where are you? Why   won't you answer? Are you angry   me? Please, please, I'm so   afraid! Don't leave me!
Wait.
Oh, Data.
That whisper in the dark has   become a plea. We cannot turn   our backs.
We've found the reason for the   geological instability.
Excellent.
We would have missed it if Ensign   Crusher hadn't requested an   Ico-gram, but he did, and...
Drema Four has the largest deposit   of dilithium ore ever recorded.   It's also laid down in a very   unusual pattern. The crystals   are growing to form perfectly   aligned lattices.
The ore is forming generator   strata.
Which creates a piezoelectric   effect.
In plain English this means that   the dilithium is causing the   geological catastrophe?
Right, the crystals take the   natural radiant heat of the planet   --
Focus it, and turn it into   mechanical energy.
That increases tectonic stresses   --
(tapping him on the     shoulder)   Excuse me, those plates are mine.   Stick to your volcanos. Anyway   the stress tears the planet   apart.
Then the crystals break down,   which is why we found all these   traces of Illium-629.
All right, we know the why. Now   what can we do?
That's going to take a little more   work.
Can we reverse the process?
We think so.
No theories or half answers. Yes   or no.
We'll get to work on it.
Sir.

Data's out there...    (indicates the bridge     with a head jerk)   ... monitoring conditions on   Drema Four. The situation's   becoming pretty desperate for his   friend. He's calculated the   safest locations on the planet's   surface. You can guess why.
We just keep getting in deeper   and deeper, don't we?
She's going to die. They're all   going to die.
Unless.
Yes... unless.
You may tell Commander Data that   he has my permission to contact   his friend and guide her to a   safer location.
Do you know where we are now,   Number One?
Sir?
Up to our necks.
Sarjenka, this is Data. Respond   please.
Unable to complete transmission.
Reason for failure?
Damage to remote receiver on   planet's surface.
We are modifying Class One probes   so they become resonators. We   will then use torpedo casings   to protect the probes once they   begin burrowing beneath the   surface.
How do these resonators destroy   the crystals?
By emitting harmonic vibrations   which will shatter the lattices.
The Enterprise will monitor and   adjust the frequency of the   resonators.
It sounds like a plan. Get   started on it.
Tea, Earl Grey, hot.
Captain, permission to beam down   to Drema Four.
What?
I have been unable to contact   Sarjenka.
I know you're worried, but   transporting to the surface is   only going to make a bad situation   worse.
I feel it is important to   determine the reason for --
Come on, Data!
Sir, your orders were to deliver   the message, correct?
Yes.
So what is the difference whether   I send the message or deliver it   personally?
A whopping big one, and you know   it.
We have come this far.
In for a penny, in for a pound,   is that what you're saying, Mister   Data?
Oh hell.
Go.
(not quite believing     it)   Sir?
Go. Handle the transport, Number   One.
Now where would you say we are?
O'Brien, take a nap. You didn't   see this, you're not involved.
Right sir, just standing here   dozing off.
Ten minutes, Data, that's it,   and if you meet anybody but   Sarjenka --
I will signal for immediate beam   out.
Commander Riker to the bridge.
Damn!
I just woke up, sir.
You know what to do?
No problem. I'll have him out   of there as smooth as ice.
Sarjenka, wait!
Do not be afraid. I am Data.
Data.       Data, you came.
Data, where have you been?
There is no time for explanations.   You and your family must leave.
We already have. We ran when the   tremors began.
Then why are you here?
My father wouldn't let us take   anything, but I had to have my   transmitter. I knew you would   come back, and I didn't want you   to find only silence -- the way   I did.
Yes, well, I am sorry about that,   but it is very complicated -- Does   your family know where you are?
No.
You cannot survive in this.
What are we going to do?
Enterprise, two to beam up.
Where are we going?
To the stars?
Yes.
There's gonna be hell to pay.
Where is Commander Riker?
On the bridge.
Where are you going?
To the bridge.
You're going to take that?
Leave her here?
Don't leave me here. Please don't   leave me.
Quite impossible.
Sir, we are three minutes from   resonator launch.
Where is he?
He'll be here.
He has brought that child aboard   my ship and onto my bridge.
I'm sure Data will have a very   good explanation.
She was frightened and did not   want to be left alone
Mister Data, would you kindly   assume your station.
Counselor, escort her to Sickbay.
It's all right, nobody's going   to hurt you.
We'll go and get a treat, and --
NO!
Captain, I will not allow her to   be in the way.
Two minutes to resonator launch.
Little one, hush, it's all right.
(interrupting, very     shrill)   NO! Leave me alone! I want Data!
Counselor, allow me. Please.
Hush, it is all right now. No   one will harm you. These are my   friends.
Take your station, Mister Data,   and keep her with you. This does   directly concern her.
Thirty seconds to resonator   launch.
I require my hand now.
Firing torpedoes.
Sensors locked on probes.
Torpedos have reached their   targets...
Resonators activated. Harmonic   sequences have begun.
What are you doing?
We are attempting to quiet your   planet. If we succeed, there will   be no more quakes, no more   volcanos.
When should the results become   evident?
Very quickly, sir.
And my parents and brothers?
If our experiment...
They will soon be safe.
Captain, sensors indicate a   planetwide reduction in tectonic   stress levels.
It's working. We did it!
You did this for me?
Sarjenka, look.
Starboard view.
There, there are your   stars.
What are you thinking?
Someday, I'm going to be here.
Data, take Sarjenka to Sickbay.
Sir, must we?
Yes.
Data and the alien are on their   way down. What would be involved   in removing all memory of her   communication with Data and her   visit to this ship?

Assuming her brain structure is   similar to ours the memories will   be stored chemically on the   neurons of the cerebral cortex.   They are also time dependent.   I'll have to scan for age of the   chemical links, and try to find   the relevant neurons. To be sure   I may have to go back weeks before   the initial contact with Data.
Well, do your best.
You have many different kinds   of people here.
Yes.
When I'm bigger can I be on your   ship?
I am certain you could.
I wish I could come with you now.
There are many things in life   which we desire but will never   receive. This is one of them.
I know, but I can still wish for   it.
Sarjenka, this is Doctor Pulaski.
Hello, dear.
Hello.
What is this?
An Elanin Singer Stone. It sings   a different song for each person.
What does it sing for you?
It does not sing for me.
Why not?
Because I am a machine.
Oh Data, I'm sorry.
Sarjenka, we're going to run a   few scans just to make sure you're   all right.
Data's going to be right with you.   Don't worry.
You did a good thing, Data.
But are we doing a good thing now?
Data, this is to protect her as   much as us.
By robbing her of her memories?
To remember you and this ship   would complicate her future. She   has to be the person she was born   to be. And you'll remember.
Sit down.
No thank you sir. It's going to   be a long time before I'm really   qualified to sit here.
You did a good job, Wes. I'm   proud of you.
Thank you, sir.
Does it get any easier?
No.
Come.
I came to thank you.
No thanks are necessary. You   reminded us that there are   obligations beyond duty.
You did not have to hold that   conference. Your decision could   have been unilateral.
One of my officers...
... One of my friends was in   trouble. I had to help him.
I am going to miss her, Captain.
That too is part of friendship,   remembrance and regrets.
Yes, sir.
And understanding that has taken   you a step closer to humanity.
